So said  Michael Silverstein  on  2002-12-17 --------------------

>I agree that Smalltalk is a much better language for learning (and
>implementing) objects. It pains me to see Java held up as an example
of
>a great OO language, without any acknowledgement of Smalltalk. For the
>last three years, I've spent approximately 50% of each day using Java
>and 50% using Smalltalk and I'm much more productive when using
>Smalltalk. That said, it would be nice if Smalltalk supported
>Interfaces, which I find extremely useful but is not yet supported in
>Smalltalk, to my knowledge.

Smalltalk supports interfaces, in a way; although it supports abstract
classes even better.

Push a method up to a superclass and, in the superclass, have the
method answer "SubclassResponsibility" or whatever the exact method
name is.

I have found that I don't want interfaces when I work with Ruby or
Smalltalk: I like the idea that handling methods has nothing to do with
type.
